image.altText: A flag with black on the top, red on the bottom and a yellow circle in the middle held up high at a gathering of people.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government was due to introduce a bill earlier this year to amend the legislation governing the return of Aboriginal land. Instead, it's shelved it — and that's received a mixed reaction.

title.children: Tasmanian government shelves plans to amend law governing return of Aboriginal land

image.altText: Man speaking in front of microphones to a group of people

props.synopsis: Tasmania's opposition and crossbench are poised to spring a no-confidence motion on deputy premier Michael Ferguson next week to see him removed from cabinet over the handling of the bungled Spirit of Tasmania ferries project.

title.children: 'A lot of butt covering going on': Tasmania's deputy premier responds as he faces talk of no-confidence motion

image.altText: London plane trees in a park.

props.synopsis: Next to Hobart's iconic Salamanca Market there are more than a dozen London plane trees providing cover and shade. Stallholders say it's time for them to go due to allergy complaints.

title.children: These trees may look pretty — but stallholders at Hobart's Salamanca Market want them gone

image.altText: A whale washed up on a beach

props.synopsis: Five sperm whales found washed up on a remote Tasmanian Island have all died, with the beach to remain closed while samples are taken.

title.children: No survivors at sperm whale stranding on Flinders Island

image.altText: A male artist with bleached blonde hair and beanie sits on couch with large green octopus toy and holds his artworks

props.synopsis: Dyscalculia, which Alfie Barker describes as being like "dyslexia but for maths", receives only a fraction of the research funding its literacy counterpart does, and experts believe that needs to change.

title.children: When you suffer from dyscalculia — like 'dyslexia but for maths' — even driving can be off limits

image.altText: Two young boys in hoodies wade into the ocean and point at dark shapes beneath the surface.

props.synopsis: Weather conditions and shifting sands temporarily reveal an ancient "elder" forest on a Tasmanian beach, preserved from thousands of years ago.

title.children: Did you miss? 📣 'Preserved' trees thousands of years old uncovered on beach after storm surge

image.altText: Special forces soldier

props.synopsis: Questions are being raised about how alleged war crimes by the Australian Defence Forces are investigated, following the response to the Brereton inquiry.

title.children: Why investigating the alleged war crimes of Australian soldiers is proving so difficult

image.altText: Albanese NBN composite

props.synopsis: The federal government is convinced its move to ban the privatisation of the NBN Co is a winner, but will voters care?

title.children: Under pressure over the Middle East, Labor is answering questions nobody asked

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple jacket gestures with her hands as she speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Retirement village residents and their families have backed calls for tougher regulation of the sector, with one saying contracts should carry a cigarette-style financial health warning and another saying the industry is a "black hole".

title.children: Daughter of former retirement village resident calls for 'financial health warning' on village contracts

image.altText: Jason Clare, wearing a suit, stands against a wall.

props.synopsis: A Labor-led Senate inquiry has recommended that a ministerial power to set international student caps at a course level be removed from the government’s proposed legislation.

title.children: Ministerial power to set course-level international student caps should be scrapped, Senate committee says

image.altText: A plume of grey smoke rises from blocks of city apartments at night-time, with lights everywhere

props.synopsis: Israeli air strikes in central and northern Gaza killed 12 people, local authorities said, including nine members of one family.

title.children: Hezbollah claims Israeli troops repelled from southern Lebanon, reports family of nine killed in Gaza air strike

image.altText: Chief Maycon, an Indigenous Krenak leader (left), is fighting a court battle against BHP

props.synopsis: Nineteen people died and vast swathes of land and waterways were damaged when BHP and local mining company Vale's tailing dam collapsed in 2015. Now, First Nations and traditional Brazilian people are lobbying ahead of a major class action.

title.children: Is your god worth $70 billion? Indigenous Brazilians think so and want BHP to pay up

image.altText: A man with grey hair and glasses raises his hand

props.synopsis: Timor-Leste's president Jose Ramos-Horta has sharply criticised exploitation in Australia's Pacific labour scheme, warning that unscrupulous employers are over-charging workers from his country for accommodation and transport.

title.children: Timor-Leste president slams exploitation in Australia's PALM scheme, cites excessive living costs

image.altText: Anthony Albanese apologises for Tourette slur

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese faces criticism for making an ableist remark in parliament by using Tourette syndrome as an insult, drawing condemnation from both the Greens and the Coalition. Here is a recap of what was said and the facts about Tourette syndrome.

title.children: The PM used a Tourette slur in Parliament. Advocates say it'll have real-life impacts

image.altText: Fatima Payman announcing new party

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's party will run candidates in both houses, but the senator was unable to identify policies or issues she would focus on.

title.children: Fatima Payman has launched her new party without any policies

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing that reads Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2024.

props.synopsis: The academy said one of the discoveries being recognised fulfils "a 50-year-old dream of predicting protein structures from their amino acid sequences".

title.children: Scientists David Baker, Demis Hassabis and John Jumper win Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 'predicting protein structures'

image.altText: Four people in camo trekking up a grassy area.

props.synopsis: Ember, Jayda, and Maverick disappeared with their father into New Zealand's mountain ranges in 2021 — they've just been seen together for the first time in years.

title.children: Tom Phillips took his children and vanished into New Zealand's mountains three years ago. They've just been spotted

image.altText: Ken McCallum

props.synopsis: MI5 director general Ken McCallum says Britain is experiencing a staggering rise in assassination attempts and other crimes by Russia and Iran.

title.children: Britain's intelligence agency says Russia is trying to create 'mayhem' in the UK

image.altText: New Zealand flag in front of civic buildings

props.synopsis: As Australians await stronger signals that a rates reprieve is imminent here, across the Tasman, New Zealand's central bank has again taken the knife to its key interest rate.

title.children: New Zealand 'doubles down' on interest rates retreat with more aggressive cut

image.altText: Barricades at a bridge Korean writing on it.

props.synopsis: North Korea's military said it will "completely cut off roads and railways" linked to South Korea and "fortify the relevant areas of our side with strong defence structures."

title.children: North Korea to 'permanently' shut border with South Korea

image.altText: A young man in a suit with short hair and sculpted facial hair smiles happily for a portrait.

props.synopsis: IBAC investigators say a former mayor of Moonee Valley City Council repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for progressing property applications.

title.children: 'God status': Mayor repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for planning help, finds IBAC report

image.altText: Satellite image of Hurricane Milton on approach to US

props.synopsis: Hurricane Milton is set to make landfall on Florida's west coast as a powerful and extremely dangerous category five storm.

title.children: Millions in Florida warned homes could become coffins when Hurricane Milton hits

image.altText: Putin, wearing an ear piece, looks over to his shoulder to the blurred profile of Trump closer in frame

props.synopsis: A new book by a Washington Post reporter claims the Republican nominee trying to return to the White House has had ongoing contact with Vladimir Putin.

title.children: New book claims Trump posted COVID tests to Putin in 2020

image.altText: Apartment buildings from a distance.

props.synopsis: Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows approvals for dwellings in Australia has fallen 6.1 per cent, with the biggest drop for approvals in medium and high-density homes. Housing experts say the decline is being caused by rising construction costs and increased risk.

title.children: Dwelling approvals fall in Australia as costs, labour shortages slow approvals for new homes

image.altText: Sheila Raymond and family members

props.synopsis: Sheila Thurlow's family is calling for an inquest into her death at a Brisbane hospital after she was injected with 1,000 times the intended dose of morphine.

title.children: Nurse 'Googled' hospital procedure night before woman was given 1,000 times the intended level of morphine

image.altText: Illustration of autonomous self-driving cars.

props.synopsis: A Choice investigation has found most of Australia's popular car brands collect and share "driver data", ranging from braking patterns to video footage and voice recognition information.

title.children: Cars are data-harvesting machines. These brands share your personal information

image.altText: Australian actor Hugo Weaving with a white beard smiling with a santa het.

props.synopsis: The trailer features Hugo Weaving, a cameo from rapper Briggs, and a dollop of tomato sauce for sweetness and that extra tang.

title.children: First look at Christmas film How To Make Gravy, based on Paul Kelly's iconic song

image.altText: Reece raises his arms as he crossed the Melbourne Marathon finish line, with the time 02:14:35 on a screen above him.

props.synopsis: Reece Edwards had enough saved for a house deposit when he was 20, but spent the money on other experiences instead. While some might see that as a "financial disaster", he has a different take.

title.children: The elite runner who is such a diligent saver, his 'guilty splurge' is a weekly banh mi

image.altText: Small fire burns in bushland undergrowth.

props.synopsis: While large burns to reduce fuel loads are the Western way, this Aboriginal-led group is training people in the traditional ways of fire management to look after the landscape.

title.children: 'Everything has a role to play': Mosaic burns taught in Aboriginal-led cultural burning workshop

image.altText: a dishevelled man sits on a cushion outside a mosque with crutches lying in front of him

props.synopsis: About 1.2 million people have been forced from their homes by Israel's bombardment and invasion, the Lebanese government says. They fill the public spaces around Beirut – footpaths, squares, churchyards and schools.

title.children: 'Look at what happened to us': Beirut's streets fill with injured and homeless after Israeli strikes

image.altText: Jacob Hersant, dressed in a white shirt and blue suit, photographed in dappled sunlight outdoors.

props.synopsis: A magistrate says Melbourne man Jacob Hersant will be sentenced to jail after being found guilty of performing a Nazi salute last year. He's the first person found guilty of breaking a new Victorian law that bans the salute.

title.children: Melbourne man found guilty of performing Nazi salute to be jailed

image.altText: A street sign for Chinamans Lane

props.synopsis: A South Australian council has voted to keep the controversial name of a rural road in Penola. A descendant of one of the first Chinese people in the area says renaming Chinamans Lane would erase a part of local history.

title.children: Council votes unanimously against changing street's 'offensive' name

image.altText: A elderly man, in his 80s, stony-faced and serious, looks directly at the camera. the photo is black and white.

props.synopsis: Gerald Murnane rarely leaves his tiny Victorian town, but bookies have him among the favourites to win this year's Nobel Prize for Literature.

title.children: Author who has never been on a plane could soon be Australia's second Nobel laureate
